item.title: Cultural distance and adaptation
item.description:
Culture can be considered a relatively stable trait of adult individuals because important parts of personality already form during adolescence. Most individuals emigrate in their adulthood, which means their cultural traits are less malleable once they start living abroad. Cultural differences to non-immigrants therefore become relatively constant distances immigrants have to deal with. Thus, it is important to better understand what role cultural distances play in adapting to a new environment, with increasing time spent abroad, and how immigrants can cope with related challenges. In this project, you will find personal work on these topics.

item.title: Cultural distance and immigrant adjustment
item.description:
Abstract

The cultural distance (CD) between the country of origin and destination country of migrants has long been considered important for adjustment in international migration. Past research has mainly followed a cost perspective, pointing to rising costs in adjustment with increasing CD, postulating a negative linear relationship. Following this logic, previous studies overlooked potential benefits of CD for adjustment. We address this gap by taking a more differentiated perspective on CD and adjustment. Using unique probability-based survey data on German migrants in 38 destination countries with a maximum length of stay of 36 months, we examined different CD-levels and their consequences for adjustment. We ran multilevel regressions for sociocultural and psychological adjustment. Importantly, our findings indicate that the CD effect on adjustment is not linear but clearly resembles an inverted-U shape for both adjustment dimensions. This result challenges the cost perspective and suggests an “optimal” range of intermediate CD as most beneficial for recent migrants’ adjustment. We conclude that the prevailing view on the consequences of CD for migrant adjustment holds true for very large CDs, but it underestimates the challenges for culturally close migrants and overlooks that a certain level of cultural dissimilarity can facilitate migrants’ adjustment.
